name: benzimidazole-compound production | benzimidazole-compound | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/781/documentation

This dataset represents the production of benzimidazole compounds (1 kg of active ingredient). Benzimidazoles are fungicidal compounds with a benzimidazole group produced by reacting ortho-phenylene diamine with a carboxylic group or a nitrile. This dataset models the production of benzimidazole compounds based on the arithmetic mean of all inputs and outputs of the production of carbendazim and ethofumesate. The raw materials are modelled with stoichiometric calculations. The energy consumption is modelled with data from a similar process. The emissions are estimated and the infrastructure is included with a default value.;References:;Nemecek T. & Kägi T. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Swiss and European Agricultural Production Systems. Final report ecoinvent V2.0 No. 15a. Agroscope Reckenholz-Taenikon Research Station ART, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Zurich and Dübendorf, CH.

From reception of precursors at the factory gate.

This activity ends with benzimidazole-compounds at the factory gate. The dataset includes the input materials, energy uses, infrastructure and emissions. The dataset doesn't include emulsives, additives etc.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/202:Manufacture of other chemical products/2021:Manufacture of pesticides and other agrochemical products

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The inventory is modelled for Europe.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Benzimidazoles are fungicidal compounds with a benzimidazole group produced by reacting ortho-phenylene diamine with a carboxylic group or a nitrile.;This dataset was calculated from the arithmetic mean of all inputs and outputs of the production of carbendazim and ethofumesate.;Carbendazim is produced in four steps from ammonium thiocyanate:;CH4N2S → CH4N2S;2 CH4N2S + C2H6O4S → C4H14N4O4S3;C4H14N4O4S3 + 2 C2H3ClO2 + 2 NaOH → 2 C4H8N2O2S + Na2SO4 + 2 H2O + 2 HCl;C4H8N2O2S + C6H8N2 → C9H9N3O2 + CH4S + NH3;Precursors that are used for the carbendazim production are methyl chloroformate (C2H3ClO2) and o-phenyl diamine (C6H8N2).;Methyl chloroformate (C2H3ClO2) is produced from methanol and phosgene:;CH4O + CCl2O → C2H3ClO2 + HCl;o-Phenyl diamine (C6H8N2) is produced in three steps from chlorobenzene:;C6H5Cl + HNO3 → C6H4ClNO2 + H2O;C6H4ClNO2 + NH3 → C6H6N2O2 + HCl;C6H6N2O2 + 3 H2 → C6H8N2 + 2 H2O;Ethofumesate is produced in four steps from aniline:;C6H7N + MnO2 + H2SO4 → C6H4O2 + MnSO4 + H2 + NH3;C6H4O2 + C4H8O → C10H12O3;C10H12O3 + C2H6O → C12H16O3 + H2O;C12H16O3 + CH3ClSO2 → C13H18O5S + HCl;Precursors that are used for the ethofumesate production are isobutyraldehyde (C4H8O), methane sulfonyl chloride (CH3ClSO2), and thionyl chloride (SOCl2).;Isobutyraldehyde (C4H8O) is produced from propylene:;C3H6 + CO + H2 → C4H8O;Methane sulfonyl chloride (CH3ClSO2) is produced in three steps from methane:;CH4 + SO3 → CH4SO3;CH4SO3 + SOCl2 → CH3ClSO2 + SO2 + HCl;Thionyl chloride (SOCl2) is produced in two steps from sulphur:;S + Cl2 → SCl2;SCl2 + SO2 + Cl2 → 2 SOCl2

exchanges.description: Benzimidazoles can have different modes of action. Carbendazim, which is a fungicide, causes ß-tubuline assembly in mitosis; and Ethofumesate, which is an herbicide, is an inhibitor of lipid synthesis, not ACCase inhibition.

flow.name: Methanol
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description: Calculated as a fraction of the input of water. For more details, refer to the mathematical relation and the parameters.

flow.name: Water
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/unspecified

exchanges.description: Estimation, based on the assumption that 0.2% of volatile input materials is emitted to air occurring from the purge vent, the distillation vent and fugitive emission sources. Remaining gases like CH4 or CO are oxidated to CO2. The carbon contained in the removed carbon compounds from wastewater treatment was accounted as CO2 emissions to air (assuming  a removal efficiency of 90%).

flow.name: Carbon dioxide, fossil
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description:
Calculated based on literature data published by the industry. For this activity, no information was readily available concerning infrastructure and land-use. Therefore, the infrastructure is estimated based on data from two chemical factories, the BASF site of Ludwigshafen and the chemical factory in Gendorf (which are both located in Germany), which produce a wide range of chemical substances. Based on this data, the following assumptions are made: the built area amounts to about 4.2 ha, the plant has an average output of 50'000 t/a and a lifespan of fifty years. The estimated infrastructure amount is therefore 4.00 E-10 units per kg of produced chemical. Furthermore, for this dataset, the infrastructure amount is accounted for each production step. This may be an overestimation in some multistep syntheses.

References:
Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.
Gendorf (2000) Umwelterklärung 2000, Werk Gendorf. Werk Gendorf, Burgkirchen.'

flow.name: Sulfur
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to water/surface water

exchanges.description:
Estimation, assuming a default value, originated from the calculation of an average consumption of electricity and heat per kg of product (3.2 MJ/kg), and a resulting amount of electricity of 0.333 kWh for every reaction step per kg reaction product, considering that the demand is made up of a mix that includes 38% electricity.  Additionally, reaction steps are approximated with energy consumption data, assuming that inventory flows can be estimated using process data for basic operation steps, available for specific organic chemicals.

Further references:
Kim S., Overcash M.: Energy in chemical manufacturing processes: gate-to-gate information for life cycle assessment. In: Journal of Chemical Technology & Biotechnology vol. 78,  no. 9: 995-1005(11). 2003

exchanges.description:
Estimation, assuming a default value, originated from the calculation of an average consumption of electricity and heat per kg of product (3.2 MJ/kg), and a resulting amount of heat of 2 MJ for every reaction step per kg reaction product, considering that the demand is made up of a mix that includes 12% steam from external energy sources.  Additionally, reaction steps are approximated with energy consumption data, assuming that inventory flows can be estimated using process data for basic operation steps, available for specific organic chemicals.

Further references:
Kim S., Overcash M.: Energy in chemical manufacturing processes: gate-to-gate information for life cycle assessment. In: Journal of Chemical Technology & Biotechnology vol. 78,  no. 9: 995-1005(11). 2003
